acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute
acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: It was classified into Category 2 from 24 hours LC50=1142microg/L of the crustacea (Daphnia magna) (AQUIRE, 2003).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is "solid" according to the GHS definition and inhalation of its gas is not expected.

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on the mouse LD50 (oral route) value of 15mg/kg (RTECS (2004)).

carcinogenicity.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is classified as Category D by EPA (1990).

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_statement: Toxic to aquatic life with long lasting effects
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since acute toxicity was Category 2 and it was a metallic compound and an underwater action and bio-accumulation were unknown, it was classified into Category 2.

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Test methods applicable to solid substances are not available

explosives.rationale: No data available though being nitrates, containing chemical groups with explosive properties. Classified into Divisions 5.1 and 6.1 (UN#2727) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods).

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases
flammable_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

flammable_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

flammable_solids.rationale: Classified into Divisions 5.1 and 6.1 (UN#2727) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods).

gases_under_pressure.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Inorganic compounds containing oxygen and classified as a powerful oxidant according to HSDB (2006). Classified as "Division 5.1: oxidizing substances" by the UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods. However, it can be included in Category 2 or 3, given the fact that it has subsidiary risks corresponding to Division 6.1 and is assigned to Packing Group II (UN#2727). The substance is placed in Category 2 from the viewpoint of safety.

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

pyrophoric_solids.rationale: Classified into Divisions 5.1 and 6.1 (UN#2727) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods).

self_reactive_substances.rationale: Classified as oxidizing solids, though being nitrates containing chemical groups with explosive properties. Classified into Divisions 5.1 and 6.1 (UN#2727) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods).

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Based on the description in the report on epidemiological studies of human exposure (HSDB (2006)): "The substance severely burns the skin and eye." The substance is thus considered to have corrosive effects on the eye.

skin_corrosion_irritation.hazard_statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Based on the description in the report on epidemiological studies of human exposure (HSDB (2006)): "The substance severely burns the skin and eye." The substance is thus considered to have corrosive effects. Although classified into Category 1A-1C, it should be placed in Category 1A from the viewpoint of safety if further subclassification is needed.

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.classification:
Category 1 (nervous system, skin, testis),
Category 2 (cardiovascular system)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement:
Cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (nervous system, skin, testis)
May cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (cardiovascular system)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale:
Based on the human evidence: "Thallium may affect the nervous system following inhalation" (ATSDR 1992), "chief complaints included abdominal pain, fatigue, irritancy, body weight reduction and pain in legs. Four patients had loss of hair" (ACGIH 2001), "clinical symptoms began with excitement and sleeplessness" (PATTY (5th 2001)), "paraesthesias and polyneuritis such as pain in muscles and joints, as well as psychasthenic symptoms such as headache, sleep disorders and fatigue" (EHC 182 (1996)), "may affect the cardiovascular/nervous systems" (IPCS (J) (2002)). 
Also based on the evidence from animal studies: "thallium caused disturbed behaviour, aggressiveness, diarrhoea, and loss of hair," "Testicular effects including disarrangement of the tubular epithelium, cytoplasmic vacuolization, and distention of the smooth endoplasmic reticulum of Sertoli cells" (EHC 182 (1996)). The effects on the cardiovascular system are classified into Category 2 since the priority rating of the referenced study is 2.

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.classification:
Category 1 (nervous system, respiratory system, cardiovascular system),
Category 2 (kidney, liver)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_statement:
Causes damage to organs (nervous system, respiratory system, cardiovascular system)
May cause damage to organs (kidney, liver)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: Based on the human evidence: "Lungs showed diffuse alveolar damage. There was extensive damage of the myocardium. Cranial and peripheral neuropathy was observed" (ATSDR (1992)), "temporary lesion of the kidneys and liver, and temporary toxic neuropathy of ocular nerve with subsequent polyneuropathy" (HSDB (2005)). The effects on the kidneys and liver are classified into Category 2 since the priority rating of the referenced study is 2.
